site.title: USM ART Coach
site.subtitle: Unified Service Management made practical
site.tagline: From framework overload to one simple, reusable method for every service organization.

chapters.title: Chapter 1 – Why USM?
chapters.tagline: From scattered best practices to one simple, reusable method.
chapters.summary: Explains why service organizations struggle with many overlapping frameworks and tools, and introduces USM as a simple, universal management method for any service provider.
keyPoints: Most organizations are overloaded with frameworks (ITIL, COBIT, ISO, Lean, Agile) but still lack consistent execution.
USM focuses on a small, universal set of processes and workflows instead of hundreds of practices.
The same management system can be used in IT, HR, Facilities, Telecom, Municipalities, etc.
USM is architecture-first: one clear structure; practices and tools plug into that structure.
Goal: service and customer excellence with less complexity, lower cost, and more control.
examples: An IT department runs ITIL, a facilities team uses its own FM standard, HR has its own processes – everyone works differently, making shared services and reporting painful.
A CIO wants one way of working across all service units; USM becomes the common language and architecture.

chapters.title: Chapter 2 – Principles & Architecture
chapters.tagline: A small set of principles that make service delivery predictable.
chapters.summary: Introduces the core principles of USM and the enterprise service management architecture (ESMA) that underpins every service organization.
keyPoints: USM is built on a handful of business principles (e.g., structure systems by segmenting them; the customer determines quality; standardization enables control).
The Enterprise Service Management Architecture (ESMA) gives a generic blueprint for any service organization.
USM separates WHAT (architecture, principles) from HOW (local practices and tools).
A single Enterprise Service Management System (ESMS) can satisfy multiple standards (ISO, COBIT, etc.) at once.
Value is co-created: services enable customer activities; quality is defined from the customer’s perspective.
examples: A municipality uses USM principles to design one service system for IT, Facilities, and HR, even though each uses different tools.
A hospital wants to meet ISO 27001 and ISO 20000; instead of separate projects, they build one USM-based management system and map both standards onto it.

chapters.title: Chapter 3 – Service & Value
chapters.tagline: Understanding services, value co-creation, and customer experience.
chapters.summary: Defines what a service really is, how value is co-created, and why a customer-driven mindset is essential for modern service organizations.
chapters.audience: Anyone who talks to customers, designs services, or owns SLAs.
keyPoints: Service = a means of enabling customer activities and outcomes, not just a product or system.
Value is co-created: provider + customer both have roles in achieving outcomes.
USM uses Service-Dominant (S-D) logic: focus on use and outcomes, not just technology.
Customer experience (CX/UX) is shaped by all interactions across workflows and touchpoints.
A clear service catalog and meaningful agreements (SAs/SLAs/OLAs/UCs) are key instruments.
examples: Instead of saying “we provide servers,” the provider defines a service like “Reliable Clinical Application Hosting” with clear outcomes and responsibilities.
A railway operator focuses on ‘on-time departure’ as a customer outcome; IT, facilities and operations all contribute via their services.

chapters.title: Chapter 4 – People, Roles & Profiles
chapters.tagline: From job titles to clear tasks, authorities and responsibilities (TAR).
chapters.summary: Describes how to structure roles, profiles, and responsibilities so that everyone knows what they must do in the management system.
chapters.audience: HR, line managers, process/workflow owners, PMO/SMO.
keyPoints: USM separates people, roles, functions, and profiles to avoid confusion.
TAR (Tasks, Authorities, Responsibilities) must be balanced; you cannot hold someone responsible without giving them authority.
Profiles (like Service Manager, Process Manager, Coordinator, Operator) can be reused across teams and domains.
The managed infrastructure register (MIR) also stores profiles and their relations to processes and workflows.
A matrix organization emerges where profiles act on processes, independent of the org chart.
examples: A ‘Change Manager’ is clarified into two profiles: Change Coordinator (line coordination) and Process Manager CHM (designs and governs the change process).
An organization maps all key profiles to USM processes and discovers overlaps and gaps in responsibilities.

chapters.title: Chapter 5 – The USM Process Model
chapters.tagline: Five universal processes, eight workflows – that’s all you need.
chapters.summary: Defines the five generic USM processes and the eight workflows that organize all service management activities in a non-redundant way.
chapters.audience: Process owners, architects, tool admins, team leads.
keyPoints: USM uses 5 processes: CTM (Agree), CHM (Change), INC (Recover), OPS (Operate), RIM (Improve).
All service management work is handled via 8 workflows (wishes, changes, incidents, service requests, etc.).
The process model is pure and non-redundant – no overlapping activities in multiple processes.
Workflows cross processes and teams, creating an integrated view of how services are delivered.
Every call in the system follows a simple pattern: accept → classify → handle → evaluate/close.
examples: A ‘New Employee Onboarding’ request triggers a workflow that uses CTM (agreements), CHM (changes like access setup), OPS (daily tasks), and RIM (improvement feedback) in one flow.
An incident on a critical system is handled via the INC workflow, but might trigger CHM (permanent fix) and RIM (risk reduction).

chapters.title: Chapter 6 – Managed Infrastructure (MIR)
chapters.tagline: Your single source of truth for services, assets, people, and documents.
chapters.summary: Explains the Managed Infrastructure Register (MIR) as the central, structured record of all facilities and management system components needed to deliver services.
chapters.audience: Tool owners, asset/config managers, architects, auditors.
keyPoints: MIR = the complete set of managed infrastructure components (MICs): services, assets, documents, profiles, workflows, tools, etc.
Everything that matters for control and repeatability is a MIC and is stored or referenced in the MIR.
Changes to MICs are controlled via CHM, ensuring traceability and impact analysis.
The MIR is broader than a classic CMDB – it includes non-technical components like procedures, agreements, training plans.
A good MIR enables better reporting, risk management, and standardization.
examples: A standard change model, a laptop build template, and a service agreement are all MICs; they live in the MIR and are changed via CHM.
During an audit, the organization quickly shows how a security policy (MIC) links to services, assets, and workflows in the MIR.

chapters.title: Chapter 7 – The Service Organization
chapters.tagline: How to structure teams, roles, and responsibilities for control.
chapters.summary: Shows how to design the service organization so that governance, structure, separation of duties, and standardization all support reliable service delivery.
chapters.audience: Executives, service management leaders, HR, architects.
keyPoints: Mission, core values, vision, strategy, goals, and objectives must be aligned and translated into concrete policy.
Governance sets the rules and oversight; management runs the day-to-day within that frame.
Planning & control works on three levels: strategic (aim), tactical (set up), operational (execute).
Separation of duties is critical: specify vs realize, process management vs line management.
USM assumes a matrix organization where teams use the same processes and workflows, regardless of hierarchy.
Standardization and domain separation provide assurance; drama triangles and shadow services are signals of organizational imbalance.
examples: IT splits functional management (requirements, SLAs, business liaison) from technical management (infrastructure & apps), with clear interfaces and USM workflows between them.
A business unit bypasses the internal IT service and buys its own SaaS tools – USM identifies this as a ‘shadow service’ and addresses the root-cause: broken trust and unclear service design.

chapters.title: Chapter 8 – Technology Resources
chapters.tagline: Tools should follow the method – not the other way around.
chapters.summary: Describes the tooling landscape for service organizations and what a USM-compatible service delivery coordination (SDC) tool must be able to do.
keyPoints: Resources include SDC/service desk tools, MIR tools, knowledge bases, PPM, reporting, monitoring, and domain-specific system management tools.
Two main strategies: ERP (all-in-one suite) vs Best-of-Breed (specialized tools integrated by APIs).
USM favors strong workflow support and an integrated MIR over monolithic tool coverage.
A USM-ready SDC tool must support all 8 workflows, templates, integral planning, and an integrated MIR.
Non-automated tools (templates, forms, documents) are still important and should be treated as MICs.
examples: A facilities organization switches from several disconnected tools to one workflow-centric SDC tool plus a few specialized point solutions connected via APIs.
A service desk tool is redesigned to use USM workflows: each request type corresponds to a template that pre-assigns tasks, teams, and timings.

chapters.title: Chapter 9 – Deploying USM
chapters.tagline: Turning USM from a book into your daily way of working.
chapters.summary: Provides a practical deployment protocol for implementing USM in a step-by-step, agile way, aligned with organizational change management.
chapters.audience: Project/program managers, internal change leads, USM coaches.
keyPoints: USM deployment is a learning process: the goal is self-sufficiency, not dependency on external consultants.
Typical phases: intake → planning → set-up → first improvement sprint → further sprints → transfer to standing organization.
A project structure with a project board, internal project manager, and (optional) USM coach guides the change.
Improvement sprints integrate people, processes, technology, and services – always in small, manageable steps.
USM is compatible with Agile, DevOps, Lean, Design Thinking, and other improvement techniques.
The USM Panel keeps continuous improvement alive after the project ends.
examples: An internal project manager leads a 6-month USM deployment with quarterly sprints, each delivering visible changes to workflows and tooling.
After the project, an operator-level USM Panel meets monthly to surface issues; process managers translate them into RIM items and CHM changes.

chapters.title: Epilogue – The House You Built
chapters.summary: Reflects on USM as a simple but robust way to architect and run service organizations, like building a house with a solid foundation and reusable components.
chapters.audience: Everyone who wants the ‘big picture’ of USM.
keyPoints: USM is not new theory; it’s a practical synthesis of proven management principles in a very simple structure.
You build your management system like a house: foundation (principles), structure (processes/workflows), installations (tools), furniture (practices).
Once the fundament is in place, you can redesign rooms and furniture without rebuilding the house.
USM works for any service organization and supports shared service centers and standardization across domains.
Using USM, you can meet multiple standards and frameworks with one coherent management system.
examples: A company merges IT, HR, and Facilities into an interdisciplinary SSC using one USM-based SDC tool and one set of workflows.
An organization uses USM as the underlying management system and maps ISO, COBIT, and local regulations on top, instead of running separate initiatives.

glossary.definition: Unified Service Management – a simple, universal method to design and run service organizations using five processes and eight workflows.
Enterprise Service Management Architecture – the generic blueprint for how any service organization should be structured.
Enterprise Service Management System – the concrete management system (processes, roles, tools, MIR) built using USM.
Contract/Agree Management process – making and managing agreements with customers and suppliers.
Change Management process – preparing, assessing, authorizing, and implementing changes.
Incident/Recover Management process – restoring normal service when something goes wrong.
Operations Management process – executing planned, repetitive operational activities.
Risk/Improve Management process – identifying risks, prioritizing improvements, and following them up.
Managed Infrastructure Register – the controlled record of all managed infrastructure components (MICs): services, assets, documents, roles, workflows, tools, etc.
Service Delivery Coordination tool (often called a service desk tool) that manages workflows, calls, and the MIR.
Service Agreement / Service Level Agreement / Operational Level Agreement / Underpinning Contract – different types of agreements that define expectations and responsibilities.
Shared Service Center / interdisciplinary Shared Service Center – merged support organizations that deliver services to multiple business units, possibly across domains.
Unofficial services created by internal customers when they bypass the official provider, leading to duplication, risk and inefficiency.
A problematic three-way relationship (e.g., customer–provider–provider) where conflicting interests and poor coordination harm overall service performance.
Tooling strategy where you select the best specialized tools for each function and integrate them, instead of using one big ERP suite.
